Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE)

Let D={Di:i=1…n}D = \{D_i:i=1\dots n\}D={Di​:i=1…n} where Di=(yi,Xi)D_i = (y_i, X_i)Di​=(yi​,Xi​) and each DiD_iDi​ is iid. Suppose that there is some parameter θ∈Θ\theta \in \Thetaθ∈Θ. Then the joint probability density function (or probability mass function) P(D∣θ)P(D\mid\theta)P(D∣θ) - or the likelihood Ln(θ)L_n(\theta)Ln​(θ) is

Ln(θ)=∏i=1nP(Di∣θ)L_n(\theta) = \prod_{i=1}^n P(D_i\mid\theta)Ln​(θ)=i=1∏n​P(Di​∣θ)

The joint PDF gives us the likelihood of the iid sample given θ\thetaθ. The negative log likelihood (NLL) then becomes

−log⁡Ln(θ)=−∑i=1nlog⁡P(Di∣θ)-\log{L_n(\theta)} = - \sum_{i=1}^n \log{P(D_i\mid\theta)}−logLn​(θ)=−i=1∑n​logP(Di​∣θ)

The goal is to have some estimate of θ\thetaθ that describes the samples that we observe. Therefore, we want to maximize the likelihood function LnL_nLn​ with respect to θ\thetaθ - or minimize the NLL. The maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) is defined as

θ^MLE∈arg⁡min⁡θ∈Θ{−log⁡Ln(θ)}\hat{{\theta}}_{MLE} \in \underset{\theta \in \Theta}{\arg \min} \{-\log{L_n(\theta)}\}θ^MLE​∈θ∈Θargmin​{−logLn​(θ)}

The MLE estimator θ^MLE\hat{{\theta}}_{MLE}θ^MLE​ is the value which we are most likely to observe DDD. In general, θ^MLE\hat{\theta}_{MLE}θ^MLE​ is obtained using some form of numerical optimization over the NLL.

Asymptotics of MLE

lim⁡n→∞θ^MLE=θ\underset{n\to\infty}{\lim}{\hat{{\theta}}_{MLE}} = \thetan→∞lim​θ^MLE​=θ

MLE is asymptotically consistent. It is also asymptotically normal and this can be proven using Stein's Lemma.

Exponential Family

If each DiD_iDi​ (or xix_ixi​) follows a distribution of an Exponential Family, then P(xi∣θ)P(x_i\mid\theta)P(xi​∣θ) follows the form

h(xi)exp⁡(η(θ)⊤s(xi))Z(θ)\frac{h(x_i)\exp(\eta(\theta)^\top s(x_i))}{Z(\theta)}Z(θ)h(xi​)exp(η(θ)⊤s(xi​))​

Examples of exponential families include

  • Bernoulli Distribution: P(xi∣θ)=θ1(xi=1)(1−θ)1(xi=0)P(x_i\mid\theta) = \theta^{1(x_i = 1)}(1-\theta)^{1(x_i = 0)}P(xi​∣θ)=θ1(xi​=1)(1−θ)1(xi​=0)
  • Categorical Distribution: P(xi∣θ)=∏c=1kθc1(xi=c)P(x_i\mid \boldsymbol{\theta}) = \prod_{c=1}^k\theta_c^{1(x_i = c)}P(xi​∣θ)=∏c=1k​θc1(xi​=c)​
  • Normal Distribution: P(xi∣μ,σ)=1σ2πexp⁡(−12(x−μσ)2)P(x_i\mid\mu,\sigma) = \frac{1}{\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp\left(-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}\right)^2\right)P(xi​∣μ,σ)=σ2π​1​exp(−21​(σx−μ​)2)
  • Multivariate Normal Distribution: P(xi∣μ,Σ)=1(2π)d2det⁡(Σ)d2exp⁡(−12(xi−μ)⊤Σ−1(xi−μ))P(\boldsymbol{x}_i\mid \boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}) = \frac{1}{(2\pi)^{\frac{d}{2}}\det(\boldsymbol{\Sigma})^{\frac{d}{2}}}\exp\left(-\frac{1}{2}(\boldsymbol{x}_i-\boldsymbol{\mu})^\top \boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{-1}(\boldsymbol{x}_i-\boldsymbol{\mu})\right)P(xi​∣μ,Σ)=(2π)2d​det(Σ)2d​1​exp(−21​(xi​−μ)⊤Σ−1(xi​−μ))
  • Poisson Distribution: P(xi∣λ)=1xi!λxiexp⁡(−λ)P(x_i \mid \lambda) = \frac{1}{x_i!}\lambda^{x_i}\exp(-\lambda)P(xi​∣λ)=xi​!1​λxi​exp(−λ)

Convenient thing about distributions that follow the exponential family is that the MLE can be obtained from moment matching - i.e., the estimator is just the sample mean (and sample covariance). Thus, there is no need for any numerical optimization method such as grid search or gradient descent.

Maximum a Posteriori (MAP) Estimation

MLE estimates θ\thetaθ by maximizing the likelihood of seeing DDD conditional on θ\thetaθ, but it's more intuitive to think of learning θ\thetaθ conditional on observing DDD - i.e. what we really want to find θ\thetaθ that has the highest prob ability given the data. From Bayes' rule we have

P(θ∣D)=P(D∣θ)P(θ)P(D)P(\theta\mid D) = \frac{P(D\mid \theta)P(\theta)}{P(D)}P(θ∣D)=P(D)P(D∣θ)P(θ)​
P(θ∣D)∝P(D∣θ)P(θ)P(\theta\mid D) \propto P(D\mid \theta)P(\theta)P(θ∣D)∝P(D∣θ)P(θ)

Note that P(θ)P(\theta)P(θ) should really be P(θ∣α)P(\theta\mid\alpha)P(θ∣α), where α\alphaα is the parameter for the prior distribution of θ\thetaθ. Following the same way MLE estimated θ\thetaθ from minimizing the NLL, the maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimator can be obtained from minimizing the NLL where Ln(θ)=P(θ∣D,α)∝P(D∣θ)P(θ∣α)L_n(\theta) = P(\theta\mid D, \alpha) \propto P(D\mid \theta)P(\theta\mid\alpha)Ln​(θ)=P(θ∣D,α)∝P(D∣θ)P(θ∣α).

θ^MAP∈arg⁡min⁡θ∈Θ{−∑i=1nlog⁡P(Di∣θ)−log⁡P(θ∣α)}\hat{{\theta}}_{MAP} \in \underset{\theta \in \Theta}{\arg \min} \left\{-\sum_{i=1}^n \log{P{(D_i\mid\theta)}} - \log{P(\theta\mid\alpha)}\right\}θ^MAP​∈θ∈Θargmin​{−i=1∑n​logP(Di​∣θ)−logP(θ∣α)}

The prior distribution acts as a regularizer, ensuring that the estimator does not overfit, particularly when the number of observations is small. Note that as n→∞n\to\inftyn→∞, θ^MAP→θ^MLE\hat{{\theta}}_{MAP} \to \hat{{\theta}}_{MLE}θ^MAP​→θ^MLE​.

Conjugate Priors

If P(D∣θ)P(D\mid \theta)P(D∣θ) follows an Exponential Family, there is a prior distribution for θ∣α\theta\mid\alphaθ∣α such that θ∣D,α\theta\mid D,\alphaθ∣D,α will belong to the same family of distributions as the prior. Some examples of conjugate priors are:

  • Beta-Bernoulli: x∣θ∼Bern(θ),θ∣α,β∼Beta(α,β)x\mid\theta \sim Bern(\theta), \theta\mid\alpha,\beta \sim Beta(\alpha,\beta)x∣θ∼Bern(θ),θ∣α,β∼Beta(α,β)
  • Categorical-Dirichlet: x∣θ∼Cat(θ),θ∣α∼Dir(α)x\mid\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim Cat(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \boldsymbol{\theta}\mid\boldsymbol{\alpha} \sim Dir(\boldsymbol{\alpha})x∣θ∼Cat(θ),θ∣α∼Dir(α)
  • Normal Distribution: x∣μ,σ∼N(μ,σ),μ∣μ0,σ0∼N(μ0,σ0)x\mid\mu,\sigma \sim N(\mu,\sigma), \mu\mid\mu_0,\sigma_0 \sim N(\mu_0,\sigma_0)x∣μ,σ∼N(μ,σ),μ∣μ0​,σ0​∼N(μ0​,σ0​)
  • Multivariate Normal Distribution: x∣μ,Σ∼N(μ,Σ),μ∣μ0,Σ0∼N(μ0,Σ0)\boldsymbol{x}\mid \boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma} \sim N(\boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}), \boldsymbol{\mu}\mid\boldsymbol{\mu}_0,\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0\sim N(\boldsymbol{\mu}_0,\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0)x∣μ,Σ∼N(μ,Σ),μ∣μ0​,Σ0​∼N(μ0​,Σ0​)
  • Gamma-Poisson Distribution: x∣λ∼Poisson(λ),λ∣α,β∼Gamma(α,β)x\mid \lambda \sim Poisson(\lambda), \lambda\mid\alpha,\beta \sim Gamma(\alpha,\beta)x∣λ∼Poisson(λ),λ∣α,β∼Gamma(α,β)
